p:
Novel correlates of protection are being explored including cellular immunity. Influenza-specific cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) have been shown to be involved in killing and removing cells that are infected with influenza viruses
9– 14 . These cells may play an important role in the clearance of influenza virus both before and after clinical symptoms appear. Influenza has been shown to stimulate CTL responses to the internal proteins PB1, PB2, PA, NP, M2, and M1 (refs.
15– 18 ), which may stimulate a broadly protective response since these proteins are not as variable as viral surface proteins that typically induce a more specific humoral response.
